user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BinSemDelete_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_BinSemDelete_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t *sem;
    int32                             return_code;

    sem = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_bin_sem_table, *token);

    if (pthread_cond_destroy(&(sem->cv)) != 0)
    {
        /* sem could be busy, i.e. some task is pending on it already.
         * that means it cannot be deleted at this time. */
        return_code = OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }
    else
    {
        /* Now that the CV is destroyed this sem is unusable,
         * so we must do our best to clean everything else.  Even if cleanup
         * does not fully work, returning anything other than OS_SUCCESS would
         * suggest to the caller that the sem is still usable which it is not.
         */
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;

        /* destroy the associated mutex --
         * Note that this might fail if the mutex is locked,
         * but there is no sane way to recover from that (see above). */
        pthread_mutex_destroy(&(sem->id));
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No code fragments modify the function parameter token itself. The parameter is only dereferenced (sem = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(..., *token)), which reads the object referred to and does not assign to or change the pointer variable token. There are no assignments to token, no pointer arithmetic on token, and token is not passed to any function that could modify the pointer variable. The subsequent calls (pthread_cond_destroy, pthread_mutex_destroy) operate on the local sem object, not on token. The OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET use takes *token (the value) rather than token, so the macro cannot alter the token pointer itself. Therefore nothing in this function appears to violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 and there are no suspicious fragments to investigate.
